an3.109:1.1: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika approached the Auspicious One, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Auspicious One said to him:
an3.109:1.2: “Householder, when the citta is unguarded, actions of body, speech, and thought are unguarded.
an3.109:1.3: For one whose actions by body, speech, and thought are unguarded, those actions are “soaked”.
an3.109:1.4: For one whose actions by, body, speech, and thought are “soaked”, those actions become rotten.
an3.109:1.5: For one whose actions of body, speech, and thought are rotten, there will not be a good death, a good passing.
an3.109:2.1: It is like a bungalow with a bad roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are unguarded.
an3.109:3.1: In the same way, when the citta is unguarded, actions of body, speech, and thought are unguarded. …
an3.109:3.4: For one whose actions of body, speech, and thought are rotten, there will not be a good death, a good passing.
an3.109:4.1: “Householder, when the citta is guarded, actions of body, speech, and thought are guarded.
an3.109:4.2: For one whose actions of body, speech, and thought are guarded, those actions do not become “soaked”.
an3.109:4.3: For one whose actions by body, speech, and thought are not “soaked”, those actions do not become rotten.
an3.109:4.4: For one whose actions of body, speech, and thought are not rotten, there will be a good death, a good passing.
an3.109:5.1: It is like a bungalow with a good roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are guarded.
an3.109:6.1: In the same way, when the citta is guarded, actions of body, speech, and thought are guarded. …
an3.109:6.4: For one whose actions of body, speech, and thought are not rotten, there will be a good death, a good passing.”
